title: PG&E is cutting power to millions of Californians in unprecedented blackout to avoid wildfires
text:
PG&E Corp., the California utility giant forced into bankruptcy by two years of devastating wildfires, is carrying out the biggest planned blackout yet to keep power lines from sparking more blazes.

PG&E began cutting electricity as part of an orchestrated shutoff that will eventually plunge almost 800,000 customers into darkness across Northern California, including parts of Napa Valley and Oakland. Cutoffs began after midnight local time Wednesday, with the first phase impacting about 513,000 customers.

“The decision to turn off power was based on forecasts of dry, hot and windy weather including potential fire risk,” PG&E said on Wednesday, adding that the utility expects the weather event to last through midday local time Thursday, bringing peak winds that are expected to reach 60 to 70 miles per hour.

Altogether, more than 2 million people may be affected, based on city estimates and the average size of a U.S. household. The city of San Francisco was outside of the shutoff zone as of Tuesday.

Never before has a utility planned such a widespread shutoff affecting so many customers at once to avoid a wildfire in California. It’s the latest testament to how climate change-driven extreme weather is forcing people and businesses alike to adapt. This week’s outage will mark the first time PG&E has coordinated a blackout in a major metropolitan area. Previous ones involved rural areas prone to wildfires.

PG&E is advising its customers to ensure they have sufficient supplies of emergency items like medicines, first aid supplies, flash lights and batteries. But some people are resorting to more extreme measures, with residents of the San Francisco Bay area checking into hotels once they found out their homes were within the outage area, according to a report by ABC 7 News.

“Most people don’t realize what an outage really means,” Marilyn Varnado, one of people, told the station. “Stop lights are not going to be working, there’s going to be a lot of crazy things going on and I just think there’s going to be some tragedies because of that,” she said.
